Where to start

There are some basic features that you need to override before you publish your garden. This is the only time youâ€™ll need to see the code, I promise.

Title

The first thing you need to do is change the siteâ€™s name from â€œLilium Digital Gardenâ€ to the actual name of your digital garden.

To do so, you have to open the file named â€œ_config.ymlâ€ with a text editor. On the very first line youâ€™ll find the siteâ€™s name, you just change that and save the file. Then youâ€™ll probably need to serve the site again, as I explained here (if youâ€™re running it locally this means stop it, run â€œbundle ecex jekyll serveâ€ again, then reload the page).

Top navigation

Top navigation is the simple menu you see above the title. You can add more pages there, but for now I suggest you to just delete the â€œDocumentâ€ and the â€œDownload Liliumâ€ links.

To do so, you have to open the â€œ_includesâ€ folder, and then open the â€œnav.htmlâ€ with a text editor. Youâ€™ll find a list of four links, all you have to do is delete these last two and save the document.

About page

Another thing youâ€™ll obviously want to edit is the â€œAboutâ€ page. You can add your personal information there, such as bio, contacts and so on. At the bottom of this page youâ€™ll find some tips on how to write on a Jekyll page (such as syntax etc).

Remember that the content of the â€œAboutâ€ page is written inside the â€œabout.mdâ€ document in the â€œ_pagesâ€ folder. âš ï¸ Make sure you edit this document and NOT the â€œabout.htmlâ€ document in the â€œ_layoutsâ€ folder.

Floating elements

The floating elements are:

  1. the â€œAbout meâ€ block you se on right bottom corner of the pages,
  2. the social icons on the â€œAboutâ€ pages.

These, of course, contains more personal information. To edit them youâ€™ll have to edit the â€œfloating-about.htmlâ€ document and the â€œfloating-social.htmlâ€ document inside the â€œ_includesâ€ folder.

For the floating about, replace the text between the â€œ<p>â€ tag and the â€œ</p>â€ tag with your own text.

For the social icons, replace my social urls with yours. I provided some other icons that are not displayed (such as LinkedIn, YouTube, Pinterest, Reddit and Twitch) inside the â€œassets/iconsâ€ folder. To replace them youâ€™ll just have to type the name of the social in this space.

Or you can add or remove icons by duplicate or delete a whole block contained between the â€œ<li>â€ and the â€œ</li>â€.

Useful Tips

Now youâ€™re free to do whatever you want with your digital garden. But before my job is done, let me give you just a couple of tips that will probably make you spare some time.

Jekyll is an amazing tool, but there are some basic rules that youâ€™ll learn soon. One of them is the language. In Jekyll we write in a language called markdown language, and thatâ€™s why your notes are stored in files that have the â€œ.mdâ€ extension.

Markdown is pretty easy to learn, itâ€™s actually just a combination of symbols, like â€œ#â€ for titles, single â€œ*â€ for italic and double for bold, and so on. Anyway, it could be useful to refer to a guide.

To make it even easier, I suggest you download a proper text editor, like Atom or Visual Studio, that can help you with any syntax mistakes. When you are ready, youâ€™ll discover how many amazing things you can create by mixing markdown with some HTLM.

Another thing that you should probably know is that to be creative does not mean to be messy. Itâ€™s much easier to use a Jekyll site if its directories are in order. So, when you create a new note, you should put it in the â€œseedsâ€ folder and remember to link it in the â€œ/seeds/index.mdâ€ page. If you want to customize that section I suggest you take a look at the Jekyll documentation.
